title: Friday, 25th August, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:02am

Yep, August rule applies. If/when we run out of things to say, we'll have run out of things to say.

PM11:02am

dammit

Was distracted by this line in a BBC report this morning

PM11:04am

It's not uncommon to see a squat white droid trundling along the streets of Greenwich, south-east London, as it delivers takeaway food to the borough's residents at 4mph.

11:04 am

PM11:05am

PM11:05am

PM11:06am

That's Greenwich south st -- but by the look of the shadow and the absence of traffic, I'd guess it's at about 5.45 in the morning, in July

PM11:06am

Anyone else seen these?

KS11:07am

Probably because they're accompanied by a team of photographers on every outing

11:06 am

Ah, right, so these are robots delivering food that need human minders to step people stealing them

I'm just speculating tbh but I can't think of any other reason why kids haven't graffitied and vandalised them

PM11:09am

Yeah, they do have minders http://metro.co.uk...ummon-one-6808269/

Chris Gillespie has been appointed Managing Director of the Provident home credit business, replacing Andy Parkinson, with immediate effect. Chris Gillespie has worked for PFG before, but stepped down from his role as Managing Director of CCD in 2013 to pursue career opportunities elsewhere. Chris Gillespie's focus as the new Managing Director will be on re-establishing relationships with customers, bringing collections back to a normal level, and stabilising the operation of the business

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Quick bit of Shore -- they're one of the successful knife catchers here (for now)

PM11:15am

In the aftermath of Monday’s disastrous profit warning, Executive Chairwoman, Manjit Wolstenhome, has moved swiftly to appoint Chris Gillespie as the new Managing Director of the struggling home collected credit business. Chris Gillespie was previously Managing Director of Provident’s home collected credit business up until his departure in 2013, so knows the business well. He will replace Andy Parkinson, who was only appointed to the role on an acting basis upon the departure of Mark Stevens in June. Luke Enoch will continue in his role as head of Satsuma and the analytics agenda for the Consumer Credit Division and will also take the role of Deputy Managing Director of the home collected credit business. Both Chris and Luke will be supported by Greg Cant, the group’s Director of Corporate Finance.

We welcome this decisive action to try and stabilise and subsequently turnaround the home collected credit business. To have found an experienced industry executive that was willing to take on the role so quickly is a small positive surprise after the week’s earlier disappointments. We look forward to hearing more about the group’s plans to turn the division around in due course, which we think will not be easy to deliver.

Yesterday we published a detailed note entitled Double or quits? in which we set out the key issues facing the group while also reinstating our positive stance with a 1,000p fair value estimates. Please contact your Shore Capital account manager if you would like to receive a copy. BUY

David Buttress has retained 250,000 of these Shares, increasing his direct shareholding in Just Eat to 750,000 Shares. The Shares have been transferred from joint ownership with the Employee Benefit Trust ("EBT") to the sole ownership of David Buttress for a consideration of £0.5767 per Share (being the threshold amount determined when the awards under the JSOP were made (the "Threshold")).

PM11:57am

Here's UBS on the DNO deal in Kurdistan

PM11:57am

Spoiler: they like it, a lot

11:57 am
PM11:57am

Permanent solution reached to Tawke and Taq Taq receivables
This morning both DNO and Genel announced that they had reached definitive binding agreements with the Kurdistan Regional Government to settle the outstanding receivable for past oil exports from the Tawke and Taq Taq fields. Both agreements involve a 5-year royalty-like revenue stream, a switch to using R-factor based calculation for entitlement revenues (rather than the current proxy mechanism), and improvements to the terms of the Tawke PSC. The terms of the agreements differ but our initial scenario analysis suggests that that both could be very accretive to NAV and near-term cash generation. We are placing our price targets for both companies under review.

PM11:57am

DNO receives an additional 20% interest in the Tawke field plus a royalty
At end-2016 DNO's share of the receivable for past Tawke sales stood at $1.14bn, and as of end-2Q this had fallen to $1.10bn. Within our DNO NAV we include the NPV of expected recovery over 2017-25 under the old repayment mechanism (5% of monthly netback revenues, pro-rated to DNO's working interest) at $370m. Including value for post-2025 recovery would increase this figure to $460m. According to the DNO, Genel and KRG statements, in exchange for making no further claim for outstanding Tawke receivables on the KRG, DNO will receive the following: 1) an additional 20% interest in the Tawke licence (the KRG's existing carried interest); 2) a five year royalty comprising 3% of gross Tawke revenues; 3) removal of future obligations including production bonuses, licence fees, and funding of a $150m water purification project.

PM11:57am

Genel receives exemption from Tawke CPB plus a royalty
At end-1H17 Genel's share of the receivable for past Tawke and Taq Taq production stood at $471m. Within our Genel NAV we had included the NPV of expected recovery over 2017-25 under the previous repayment mechanism at $150m, and including value for post-2025 recovery would increase this figure to $185m. According to the statements, in exchange for making no further claim on outstanding Tawke and Taq Taq receivables, Genel will receive the following: 1) elimination of capacity building payments on Genel's share of Tawke entitlement (which were 30% of profit oil); 2) a five year royalty comprising 4.5% of gross Tawke revenues; 3) removal of outstanding PSC obligations and PSC liabilities on Taq Taq and Tawke totalling $30m net to Genel.

11:57 am
PM11:58am

So they haven't quantified all that -- in terms of a price target

PM11:58am
